##

CVE-2024-43044
(9.1 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-08-07T18:16:38

3 posts

Jenkins uses the Remoting library (typically `agent.jar` or `remoting.jar`) for the communication between controller and agents. This library allows agents to load classes and classloader resources from the controller, so that Java objects sent from the controller (build steps, etc.) can be executed on agents. In addition to individual class and resource files, Remoting also allows Jenkins plugin

3 repos

https://github.com/jenkinsci-cert/SECURITY-3430

https://github.com/v9d0g/CVE-2024-43044-POC

https://github.com/HwMex0/CVE-2024-43044

screaminggoat at 2024-08-06T20:15:19.493Z ##

Google Chrome security advisory: Stable Channel Update for Desktop
Google does not know how to count past five as they state 5 security fixes but list 6 externally reported vulnerabilities:

  1. CVE-2024-7532 (critical) Out of bounds memory access in ANGLE
  2. CVE-2024-7533 (high) Use after free in Sharing.
  3. CVE-2024-7550 (high) Type Confusion in V8.
  4. CVE-2024-7534 (high) Heap buffer overflow in Layout
  5. CVE-2024-7535 (high): Inappropriate implementation in V8
  6. CVE-2024-7536 (high) Use after free in WebAudio.

No mention of exploitation.

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-05T13:22:29.000Z ##

SonicWall: SonicWall Discovers Second Critical Apache OFBiz Zero-Day Vulnerability
Does SonicWall understand what a zero-day is?? They provide no evidence that anyone else knew of this vulnerability prior to the vendor patching. "SonicWall is unaware of any active exploitation."
SonicWall provides a root cause analysis of CVE-2024-38856 (submitter assigned 9.8 critical, disclosed 05 August 2024) Incorrect Authorization vulnerability in Apache OFBiz, which they consider a pre-auth remote code execution. They were able to bypass a patch for CVE-2024-36104 (path traversal). No Proof of Concept exploit provided.

#CVE_2024_38856 #ApacheOFbiz #vulnerability #CVE

screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-05T16:38:30.000Z ##

SonarSource: Government Emails at Risk: Critical Cross-Site Scripting Vulnerability in Roundcube Webmail
SonarSource discloses cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities in Roundcube:

  • CVE-2024-42008 (high?) XSS
  • CVE-2024-42009 (critical?) XSS
  • CVE-2024-42010 unknown

Why you should care about CVE-2024-42008, CVE-2024-42009, CVE-2024-42010:
CISA added a whopping SEVEN RoundCube CVEs to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog, four of them are XSS. As SonarSource noted, "In October 2023, ESET Research reported that a similar vulnerability was actively used by the APT group Winter Vivern to attack European government entities."

screaminggoat at 2024-08-06T17:09:56.987Z ##

JetBrains security advisory: TeamCity 2024.07.1 Bug Fix Is Out
This is one of the few JetBrains blog posts that acknowledges security fixes. The last one is from 27 June 2024. "This bug fix update resolves over 30 issues..." and TeamCity 2024.07.1 Release Notesï»¿ states "6 security problems have been fixed." Their Security Bulletin is worthless because it hasn't been updated yet. A quick check of TeamCity in CVE.mitre.org shows 1 new CVE ID for 06 August 2024: CVE-2024-43114 (7.8 high) In JetBrains TeamCity before 2024.07.1 possible privilege escalation due to incorrect directory permissions. No mention of exploitation in the JetBrains blog post.

1 posts

Use After Free vulnerability in Arm Ltd Bifrost GPU Kernel Driver, Arm Ltd Valhall GPU Kernel Driver, Arm Ltd Arm 5th Gen GPU Architecture Kernel Driver allows a local non-privileged user to make improper GPU memory processing operations to gain access to already freed memory.This issue affects Bifrost GPU Kernel Driver: from r41p0 through r49p0; Valhall GPU Kernel Driver: from r41p0 through r49p0

screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-06T11:36:07.000Z ##

ARM security advisory: Mali GPU Driver Vulnerabilities
Normally I don't care about Arm vulnerabilities but since there's been a string of exploited zero-days in the past, I figured I'd keep tabs on it. 2 vulnerabilities: CVE-2024-2937 and CVE-2024-4607 both have the same title (Mali GPU Kernel Driver allows improper GPU memory processing operations), affected products and description. No mention of exploitation.

#Cisco has listed three vulnerabilities.

Ankitects:

Anki Flask Invalid Path Reflected Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerability CVE-2024-32484 https://talosintelligence.com/vulnerability_reports/TALOS-2024-1995

Anki MPV script injection vulnerability CVE-2024-26020 https://talosintelligence.com/vulnerability_reports/TALOS-2024-1993 @TalosSecurity #cybersecurity #infosec

CVE-2024-7029
(8.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-08-02T15:31:27

1 posts

Commands can be injected over the network and executed without authentication.

1 repos

#search_error

screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-02T11:54:19.000Z ##

Security Week: CISA Warns of Avtech Camera Vulnerability Exploited in Wild
In yesterday's CISA ICS Advisory AVTECH IP Camera, CISA includes the following verbiage:

ATTENTION: Exploitable remotely/low attack complexity/public exploits are available/known public exploitation

Additionally, "An anonymous third-party organization confirmed Akamai's report and identified specific affected products and firmware versions." AVTECH SECURITY Corporation has not responded to requests to work with CISA to mitigate these vulnerabilities.

So there you have it CVE-2024-7029 (8.8 high) command injection vulnerability is likely an unpatched and exploited zero-day.

#CVE_2024_7029 #activeexploitation #zeroday #vulnerability #cve #avtech #cisa

CVE-2024-39396
(5.5 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.05%

updated 2024-08-02T09:31:39

1 posts

InDesign Desktop versions ID18.5.2, ID19.3 and earlier are affected by an out-of-bounds read vulnerability that could lead to disclosure of sensitive memory. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to bypass mitigations such as ASLR. Exploitation of this issue requires user interaction in that a victim must open a malicious file.

screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-05T22:08:31.000Z ##

Adobe quietly updated a 09 July 2024 security advisory for Adobe InDesign (APSB24-48), adding two vulnerabilities on 01 August 2024:

  • CVE-2024-39392 (7.8 high) Heap-based Buffer Overflow > Arbitrary code execution
  • CVE-2024-39396 (5.5 medium) Out-of-bounds Read > Memory leak (information disclosure)

No mention of exploitation.

#CVE_2024_39392 #CVE_2024_39396 #Adobe #InDesign #vulnerability #CVE #PatchTuesday

1 posts

InDesign Desktop versions ID18.5.2, ID19.3 and earlier are affected by a Heap-based Buffer Overflow vulnerability that could result in arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user. Exploitation of this issue requires user interaction in that a victim must open a malicious file.

  • CVE-2024-39392 (7.8 high) Heap-based Buffer Overflow > Arbitrary code execution
  • CVE-2024-39396 (5.5 medium) Out-of-bounds Read > Memory leak (information disclosure)

Product: OFBiz

##
screaminggoat at 2024-08-07T14:15:48.703Z ##

CISA: CISA Adds Two Known Exploited Vulnerabilities to Catalog
Hot off the press! CISA adds two CVEs to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog:

  • CVE-2024-32113 (9.1 critical) Apache OFBiz Path Traversal Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-36971 (7.8 high) Android Kernel Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

EDIT: In case anyone is wondering why it says "Access Denied", I'm too quick for CISA, and they haven't officially published the blog post. It will be available sometime in the next few hours.

#CVE_2024_32113 #CVE_2024_36971 #eitw #activeexploitation #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #vulnerability #CVE #Apache #OFbiz #Android

##
screaminggoat at 2024-08-06T16:18:01.677Z ##

@da_667 My takeaway is that CVE-2024-38856 is a patch-bypass of CVE-2024-36104, which is a path traversal. I had an issue with SonicWall calling it a zero-day, which implied that it was known to threat actors. No evidence given.

PoC diffing with https://github.com/Mr-xn/CVE-2024-32113

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-07T14:15:48.000Z ##

CISA: CISA Adds Two Known Exploited Vulnerabilities to Catalog
Hot off the press! CISA adds two CVEs to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog:

  • CVE-2024-32113 (9.1 critical) Apache OFBiz Path Traversal Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-36971 (7.8 high) Android Kernel Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

EDIT: In case anyone is wondering why it says "Access Denied", I'm too quick for CISA, and they haven't officially published the blog post. It will be available sometime in the next few hours.

#CVE_2024_32113 #CVE_2024_36971 #eitw #activeexploitation #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #vulnerability #CVE #Apache #OFbiz #Android

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-06T16:18:01.000Z ##

@da_667 My takeaway is that CVE-2024-38856 is a patch-bypass of CVE-2024-36104, which is a path traversal. I had an issue with SonicWall calling it a zero-day, which implied that it was known to threat actors. No evidence given.

PoC diffing with https://github.com/Mr-xn/CVE-2024-32113

##

CVE-2024-41611
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-08-01T15:33:24

2 posts

In D-Link DIR-860L REVA FIRMWARE PATCH 1.10..B04, the Telnet service contains hardcoded credentials, enabling attackers to log in remotely to the Telnet service and perform arbitrary commands.

screaminggoat at 2024-08-07T17:04:48.306Z ##

Sometimes it's worth checking out CISA's Vulnerability Summary, just to see what the cyber publications missed. For example in Monday's Vulnerability Summary for the Week of July 29, 2024, you'll see that D-Link, a Taiwanese networking/telecoms hardware company, has two vulnerabilities CVE-2024-41610 and CVE-2024-41611 with a CVSSv3.1 score of 9.8 critical and reads "contains hardcoded credentials in the Telnet service, enabling attackers to log in remotely to the Telnet service and perform arbitrary commands."

D-Link doesn't even list CVE IDs on their dedicated security advisories page.

And this is not the first time D-Link has been caught with hardcoded credentials:

  • 09 September 2017 by @campuscodi: Researcher Publishes Details on Unpatched D-Link Router Flaws
  • 02 July 2019 by @serghei: D-Link Settles FTC Lawsuit, Promises to Enhance Device Security
  • 16 July 2021: D-Link issues hotfix for hard-coded password router vulnerabilities
  • 06 April 2024: Over 92,000 exposed D-Link NAS devices have a backdoor account
    • 08 April 2024: Critical RCE bug in 92,000 D-Link NAS devices now exploited in attacks

At this rate, I wouldn't trust that a D-Link product doesn't have hardcoded credentials baked in. smh.

#Dlink #vulnerability #CVE_2024_41610 #CVE_2024_41611

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-07T17:04:48.000Z ##

##

CVE-2024-6387
(8.1 HIGH)

EPSS: 71.47%

updated 2024-07-30T03:31:55

2 posts

A signal handler race condition was found in OpenSSH's server (sshd), where a client does not authenticate within LoginGraceTime seconds (120 by default, 600 in old OpenSSH versions), then sshd's SIGALRM handler is called asynchronously. However, this signal handler calls various functions that are not async-signal-safe, for example, syslog().

CVE-2021-44228
(10.0 CRITICAL)

updated 2024-07-25T20:12:11

4 posts

# Summary Log4j versions prior to 2.16.0 are subject to a remote code execution vulnerability via the ldap JNDI parser. As per [Apache's Log4j security guide](https://logging.apache.org/log4j/2.x/security.html): Apache Log4j2 <=2.14.1 JNDI features used in configuration, log messages, and parameters do not protect against attacker controlled LDAP and other JNDI related endpoints. An attacker who

dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev@dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev at 2024-08-15T13:11:00.000Z ##

committed; sq; CSVs Are Kinda Bad

Three data-focused resources are on tap for this fine Thursday!

Type your emailâ¦

Subscribe

TL;DR

(This is an AI-generated summary of todayâs Drop using Sonnet via Perplexity.)

  • committed: A utility for monitoring GitHub repository changes via Atom feeds, available in Bash and Go versions (https://codeberg.org/hrbrmstr/committed)
  • sq: A versatile command-line tool for data wrangling and querying across various structured data sources, combining SQL functionality with jq-like querying (https://sq.io/)
  • CSVs Are Kinda Bad: A proposal to replace CSV with DSV (Delimiter-Separated Values) using ASCII separator characters, improving data handling and parsing (https://matthodges.com/posts/2024-08-12-csv-bad-dsv-good/)

committed

[ð¼ dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-contâ¦]Photo by Tara Winstead on Pexels.com

Longtime Drop readers may remember that I moved to Codeberg for all my public/social coding development/projects. However, my workplace still makes heavy use of GitHub, and a number of projects I rely on both inside and outside the work context are firmly entrenched in Microsoftâs horrid ecosystem.

Some of said reliant repos are ones that use GitHub and GitHub actions as a means to maintain a dataset, like my one that archives CISAâs KEV catalog. That particular repo is kind enough to have an associated GitHub repo website that makes the datasets available directly via a web request. The ones that do not forces the need to pull the latest changes. Writing a scheduled job to just pull a repo regularly and git diff whatâs changed is somewhat wasteful of resources, and may not be run frequently enough to catch critical repo updates.

Thankfully GitHub provides Atom feeds for all sorts of elements in its ecosystem.

There are Atom feeds for:

  • issues (https://github.com/{owner}/{repo}/issues.atom)
  • releases (https://github.com/{owner}/{repo}/releases.atom)
  • users (https://github.com/{username}.atom)

and more, including commits (https://github.com/{owner}/{repo}/commits/{branch}.atom). So, my KEV one would bd https://github.com/hrbrmstr/cisa-known-exploited-vulns/commits.atom.

Since polling these Atom feeds are far less bandwidth intensive, we can poll them pretty frequently from an external system, then check to see if the latest commit is different than the last one we pulled, and have that trigger an action.

There are absolutely systems and frameworks that can help with such an idiom, but I threw together a small utility I dubbed committed that is super focused on this singular task and strives to be as easy to use as possible (this, along with work and personal committments are the reason for no Drop yesterday).

There are two versons of committed in that Codeberg repo:

  • committed.sh is a pure Bash script that relies on the availablilty of curl and sed to accomplish the above task
  • thereâs also a small Golang CLI in the repo meant more to be a starting point to expand upon in the event you have more programmatic-intensive actions to perform on a repo change and do not want to rely on adding third-party shell utilities/commands (especially handy for a lambda function so you can just ship a single compiled binary vs. all those deps).

Just supply:

  • a commit hash cache file
  • an Atom feed URL
  • path to a command to run

to either version of committed, and let it do its thing.

On first run, it will just cache the latest commit hash, so you should seed said cache with garbage if you want it to do something on that first run. Hereâs a toy example for that:

# seed the cachetmpCache=$(mktemp)echo "${RANDOM}" > "${tmpCache}"committed.sh "${tmpCache}" "https://github.com/trickest/cve/commits.atom" fortune# OR, for the Go versioncommited -last-commit "${tmpCache}" -feed-url "https://github.com/trickest/cve/commits.atom" -execute fortune

Itâs MIT licensed so go bonkers with it, and please ignore/forgive the terrible sed regex hack I made to avoid reliance on a third-party XML tool.

sq

[ð¼ dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-contâ¦]

sq (GH) is a fairly new-ish command-line tool engineered for data wrangling and querying across a diverse array of structured data sources. It seamlessly integrates SQL database functionality with jq-like querying capabilities, and serves as a kind of âSwiss Army Knifeâ for data manipulation and analysis. A short, one-line descriptions might be âjq for SQL sourcesâ, but thatâs not doing it justice.

Along with the superpower of letting folks use familiar jq syntax for queries, sq helps unity multi-source querying across many data sources, including SQL databases such as SQLite, PostgreSQL, MySQL, and SQL Server, while also handling document formats like CSV, Excel, and JSON.

This tool makes it dead simple to handle cross-source joins (something I really like[d] about Apache Drill, and do like about duckd). This lets us, say, merge an Excel worksheet with a PostgreSQL table (which should really be illegal, and probably is in Florida). Itâs fairly diverse on the output side as well, with support for multiple formats, including JSON, CSV, Excel, HTML, Markdown, and XML (that last one should also be illegal in 2024).

Itâs not just a query tool, too, as it also lets us perform direct data insertion into database tables.

sq also has inspection and diffing commands that enable comparing data across sources or tables. And, itâs even a lightweight database admin tool, letting us perform management tasks like copying, truncating, and dropping tables.

This is the commands overview:

  • add: Add data source
  • src: Get or set active data source
  • group: Get or set active group
  • ls: List sources and groups
  • mv: Move/rename sources and groups
  • rm: Remove data source or group
  • inspect: Inspect data source schema and stats
  • ping: Ping data sources
  • sql: Execute DB-native SQL query or statement
  • tbl: Useful table actions (copy, truncate, drop)
  • db: Useful database actions
  • diff: BETA: Compare sources, or tables
  • driver: Manage drivers
  • config: Manage config
  • cache: Manage cache

Hereâs a short example, but the documentation site and GitHub are extremely well-documented, with plenty more examples, tutorials, and cookbook items to peruse:

$ curl --silent --fail --output inthewild.db "https://pub-4c1eae2a180542b19ea7c88f1e4ccf07.r2.dev/inthewild.db"$ sq add ./inthewild.db --handle @itw@itw  sqlite3  inthewild.db$ sq inspect @itwSOURCE  DRIVER   NAME          FQ NAME            SIZE     TABLES  VIEWS  LOCATION@itw    sqlite3  inthewild.db  inthewild.db.main  130.7MB  4       0      sqlite3:///Users/hrbrmstr/projects/sq/inthewild.dbNAME              TYPE   ROWS    COLS_litestream_lock  table  0       id_litestream_seq   table  1       id, seqexploits          table  99990   id, referenceURL, timeStamp, source, typevulns             table  260013  id, referenceURL, description, lastUpdated$ sq --src @itw sql "SELECT id, lastUpdated FROM vulns LIMIT 5"id             lastUpdatedCVE-1999-0001  2010-12-16CVE-1999-0002  2009-01-26CVE-1999-0003  2018-10-30CVE-1999-0004  2018-10-12CVE-1999-0005  2008-09-09$ sq --json --src @itw '.vulns | where(.id == "CVE-2021-44228") | .description'[  {    "description": "Apache Log4j2 2.0-beta9 through 2.15.0â¦"  }]

Having just said many nice thing about this tool, the sweet spot for it seems to be letting folks who prefer jq syntax over SQL use jq syntax on SQL data sources. I still prefer SQL over any other query language, so Iâll be sticking with duckdb, which has all of the other superpowers wrapped in an ALL CAPS (not really necessary) relational algebra.

Oh, and the shell completions sq installs are some of the best Iâve ever seen. Check it out just for those.

CSVs Are Kinda Bad

[ð¼ dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-contâ¦]

Super quick section!

Matt Hodges makes a case for abandoning the venerable CSV format in favor of substituting out commas (or tabs/pipes/etc) for ASCII separator characters, which are:

  • â File separator character: separates logical records
  • â Group separator character: separates fields
  • â Record separator character: separates repeated subfields
  • â Unit separator character: separates information items

Itâs a good read that also shows how to make a basic Python package.

I think itâs kind of a shame we also donât see more use of these ASCII characters in other contexts. In particular, I kind of wish there was more json-seq out there.

FIN

Remember, you can follow and interact with the full text of The Daily Dropâs free posts on Mastodon via @dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev@dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev â®ï¸

https://dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/2024/08/15/drop-517-2024-08-15-thursdataday/

Tap this and start free trial to see the new interface and the API (also has integrations into Splunk, Cortex, Nucleus,.etc).

kurtseifried@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-05T02:58:07.000Z ##

@bcdavid @brianleroux #log4j didn't results in massive flight cancellations for example.

The primary cost of log4j was remediation, not BSOD'ed computers taking out other services.

While there was exploitation of log4j (even prior to it being public, e.g. https://blog.cloudflare.com/exploitation-of-cve-2021-44228-before-public-disclosure-and-evolution-of-waf-evasion-patterns) but even that was barely a blip.

CVE-2024-3596(CVSS UNKNOWN)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-07-23T09:30:39

2 posts

RADIUS Protocol under RFC 2865 is susceptible to forgery attacks by a local attacker who can modify any valid Response (Access-Accept, Access-Reject, or Access-Challenge) to any other response using a chosen-prefix collision attack against MD5 Response Authenticator signature.

  • FG-IR-22-445 CVE-2022-45862 (3.7 low) GUI Console WebSockets do not terminate on logout
  • FG-IR-24-012 CVE-2024-36505 (5.1 medium) Real-time file system integrity checking write protection bypass
  • FG-IR-22-047 CVE-2022-27486(6.7 medium) OS command injections in execute CLI commands
  • FG-IR-24-255 RADIUS Protocol CVE-2024-3596 (Fortinet gives it a 6.5 medium) aka #BlastRADIUS

  • FG-IR-23-088 CVE-2023-26211 (6.8 medium) XSS vulnerability in communications triggered in playbooks

CVE-2024-38054
(7.8 HIGH)

updated 2024-07-11T18:32:20

I'm still trying to figure out what Kernel Streaming WOW Thunk :thinking: Service is, but anyway: Proof of Concept for CVE-2024-38054 (7.8 high, disclosed 09 July 2024 by Microsoft) Kernel Streaming WOW Thunk Service Driver Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability was dropped.

#CVE_2024_38054 #Microsoft #proofofconcept #poc #vulnerability #CVE

##

CVE-2024-24974
(7.5 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.06%

updated 2024-07-11T15:31:50

3 posts

The interactive service in OpenVPN 2.6.9 and earlier allows the OpenVPN service pipe to be accessed remotely, which allows a remote attacker to interact with the privileged OpenVPN interactive service.

screaminggoat at 2024-08-11T14:36:15.878Z ##

Microsoft: Chained for attack: OpenVPN vulnerabilities discovered leading to RCE and LPE
I didn't write about this earlier because more pressing issues were coming out (such as all the unpatched vulnerabilities from Microsoft, Ivanti, Fortinet and Cisco)
Microsoft found multiple medium severity vulnerabilities in OpenVPN:

  • CVE-2024-27459 (7.5 high) Denial of service (DoS), local privilege escalation (LPE) for Windows
  • CVE-2024-24974 (7.5 high) Unauthorized access
  • CVE-2024-27903 (NVD 9.8 critical) Remote code execution (RCE) for Windows, Local privilege escalation (LPE), data manipulation for Android, iOS, macOS, BSD
  • CVE-2024-1305 (9.8 critical) Denial of service (DoS)

This was presented at Black Hat USA 2024. Microsoft provides an overview of OpenVPN, a technical analysis and vulnerability analyses. This includes remote code execution by chaining CVE-2024-24974 and CVE-2024-27903, or local privilege execution using CVE-2024-27459 and CVE-2024-27903. Microsoft provides mitigation and protection guidance (hunting queries).

#OpenVPN #vulnerability #CVE #CVE_2024_27459 #CVE_2024_24974 #CVE_2024_27903 #CVE_2024_1305

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-11T14:36:15.000Z ##

##

CVE-2024-27459
(7.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-07-11T15:31:50

2 posts

The interactive service in OpenVPN 2.6.9 and earlier allows an attacker to send data causing a stack overflow which can be used to execute arbitrary code with more privileges.

screaminggoat at 2024-08-11T14:36:15.878Z ##

Microsoft: Chained for attack: OpenVPN vulnerabilities discovered leading to RCE and LPE
I didn't write about this earlier because more pressing issues were coming out (such as all the unpatched vulnerabilities from Microsoft, Ivanti, Fortinet and Cisco)
Microsoft found multiple medium severity vulnerabilities in OpenVPN:

  • CVE-2024-27459 (7.5 high) Denial of service (DoS), local privilege escalation (LPE) for Windows
  • CVE-2024-24974 (7.5 high) Unauthorized access
  • CVE-2024-27903 (NVD 9.8 critical) Remote code execution (RCE) for Windows, Local privilege escalation (LPE), data manipulation for Android, iOS, macOS, BSD
  • CVE-2024-1305 (9.8 critical) Denial of service (DoS)

This was presented at Black Hat USA 2024. Microsoft provides an overview of OpenVPN, a technical analysis and vulnerability analyses. This includes remote code execution by chaining CVE-2024-24974 and CVE-2024-27903, or local privilege execution using CVE-2024-27459 and CVE-2024-27903. Microsoft provides mitigation and protection guidance (hunting queries).

CVE-2024-27903
(7.2 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.07%

updated 2024-07-11T15:31:50

3 posts

OpenVPN plug-ins on Windows with OpenVPN 2.6.9 and earlier could be loaded from any directory, which allows an attacker to load an arbitrary plug-in which can be used to interact with the privileged OpenVPN interactive service.

screaminggoat at 2024-08-11T14:36:15.878Z ##

  • CVE-2024-1305 (9.8 critical) Denial of service (DoS)

This was presented at Black Hat USA 2024. Microsoft provides an overview of OpenVPN, a technical analysis and vulnerability analyses. ##

CVE-2024-1305
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-07-09T18:31:47

2 posts

tap-windows6 driver version 9.26 and earlier does not properly check the size data of incomming write operations which an attacker can use to overflow memory buffers, resulting in a bug check and potentially arbitrary code execution in kernel space

screaminggoat at 2024-08-11T14:36:15.878Z ##

I didn't write about this earlier because more pressing issues were coming out (such as all the unpatched vulnerabilities from Microsoft, Ivanti, Fortinet and Cisco)

  • CVE-2024-27459 (7.5 high) Denial of service (DoS), local privilege escalation (LPE) for Windows
  • CVE-2024-24974 (7.5 high) Unauthorized access

  • CVE-2024-1305 (9.8 critical) Denial of service (DoS)

This was presented at Black Hat USA 2024. Microsoft provides an overview of OpenVPN, a technical analysis and vulnerability analyses. ##

CVE-2024-38058
(6.8 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.05%

updated 2024-07-09T18:31:00

2 posts

BitLocker Security Feature Bypass Vulnerability

screaminggoat at 2024-08-14T01:29:47.665Z ##

Microsoft Security Response Center (MSRC) unexpectedly disabled fixes for CVE-2024-38058 (6.8 medium, disclosed 09 July 2024 by Microsoft) BitLocker Security Feature Bypass Vulnerability because of firmware incompatibility issues that were causing BitLocker to go into recovery mode on some devices.

Customers who want to be protected from the vulnerability can apply the mitigations described in KB5025885.

#CVE_2024_38058 #Microsoft #MSRC #vulnerability #CVE #Bitlocker

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-14T01:29:47.000Z ##

Microsoft Security Response Center (MSRC) unexpectedly disabled fixes for CVE-2024-38058 (6.8 medium, disclosed 09 July 2024 by Microsoft) BitLocker Security Feature Bypass Vulnerability because of firmware incompatibility issues that were causing BitLocker to go into recovery mode on some devices.

Customers who want to be protected from the vulnerability can apply the mitigations described in KB5025885.

#CVE_2024_38058 #Microsoft #MSRC #vulnerability #CVE #Bitlocker

CVE-2024-38100
(7.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-07-09T18:30:53

2 posts

Windows File Explorer Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability

1 repos

#search_error

screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-05T17:04:03.000Z ##

Currently trending on the bad place (Twitter): Leaked Wallpaper
Proof of concept for CVE-2024-38100 (7.8 high, disclosed 09 July 2024 by Microsoft Windows File Explorer Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability.

This is a privilege escalation tool (fixed with CVE-2024-38100 in KB5040434) that allows us to leak a user's NetNTLM hash from any session on the computer, even if we are working from a low-privileged user.

#CVE_2024_38100 #microsoft #msrc #vulnerability #CVE #proofofconcept #PoC

CVE-2024-36104
(9.1 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 0.06%

updated 2024-07-03T18:44:12

3 posts

Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal') vulnerability in Apache OFBiz.Â This issue affects Apache OFBiz: before 18.12.14. Users are recommended to upgrade to version 18.12.14, which fixes the issue.

Nuclei template

2 repos

https://github.com/Mr-xn/CVE-2024-32113

https://github.com/ggfzx/CVE-2024-36104

screaminggoat at 2024-08-06T16:18:01.677Z ##

@da_667 My takeaway is that CVE-2024-38856 is a patch-bypass of CVE-2024-36104, which is a path traversal. I had an issue with SonicWall calling it a zero-day, which implied that it was known to threat actors. No evidence given.

PoC diffing with https://github.com/Mr-xn/CVE-2024-32113

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-06T16:18:01.000Z ##

@da_667 My takeaway is that CVE-2024-38856 is a patch-bypass of CVE-2024-36104, which is a path traversal. I had an issue with SonicWall calling it a zero-day, which implied that it was known to threat actors. No evidence given.

PoC diffing with https://github.com/Mr-xn/CVE-2024-32113

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-05T13:22:29.000Z ##

SonicWall: SonicWall Discovers Second Critical Apache OFBiz Zero-Day Vulnerability
Does SonicWall understand what a zero-day is?? They provide no evidence that anyone else knew of this vulnerability prior to the vendor patching. "SonicWall is unaware of any active exploitation."
SonicWall provides a root cause analysis of CVE-2024-38856 (submitter assigned 9.8 critical, disclosed 05 August 2024) Incorrect Authorization vulnerability in Apache OFBiz, which they consider a pre-auth remote code execution. They were able to bypass a patch for CVE-2024-36104 (path traversal). No Proof of Concept exploit provided.

#CVE_2024_38856 #ApacheOFbiz #vulnerability #CVE

pfSense pfBlockerNG through 2.1.4_26 allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary OS commands as root via shell metacharacters in the HTTP Host header. NOTE: 3.x is unaffected.

##

CVE-2024-36971
(7.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.10%

updated 2024-06-27T12:30:48

11 posts

In the Linux kernel, the following vulnerability has been resolved: net: fix __dst_negative_advice() race __dst_negative_advice() does not enforce proper RCU rules when sk->dst_cache must be cleared, leading to possible UAF. RCU rules are that we must first clear sk->sk_dst_cache, then call dst_release(old_dst). Note that sk_dst_reset(sk) is implementing this protocol correctly, while __dst_ne

thleemhuisfoss@social.tchncs.de at 2024-08-08T14:18:20.000Z ##

2/ Nein, ich weiÃ die richtige Antwort auf diese Frage auch nicht.

Nach einem kurzen Blick auf https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-36971 scheint es eine LÃ¼cke zu sein, die im Linux genannten Kernel geschlossen wurde, auf dem der Kernel von Android basiert. Damit dÃ¼rfte die LÃ¼cke also auch in von anderen Herstellern genutzten Kerneln (vielleicht bei FritzBoxen) enthalten sein und mÃ¼sste womÃ¶glich eher als Linux-LÃ¼cke deklariert werden, selbst wenn die bei den Kerneln von Linux-Distris vielleicht irrelevant ist.

##
cisakevtracker@mastodon.social at 2024-08-07T15:01:03.000Z ##

CVE ID: CVE-2024-36971
Vendor: Android
Product: Kernel
Date Added: 2024-08-07
Vulnerability: Android Kernel Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
Notes: https://source.android.com/docs/security/bulletin/2024-08-01
CVE URL: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-36971

##
screaminggoat at 2024-08-07T14:15:48.703Z ##

CISA: CISA Adds Two Known Exploited Vulnerabilities to Catalog
Hot off the press! CISA adds two CVEs to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog:

  • CVE-2024-32113 (9.1 critical) Apache OFBiz Path Traversal Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-36971 (7.8 high) Android Kernel Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

EDIT: In case anyone is wondering why it says "Access Denied", I'm too quick for CISA, and they haven't officially published the blog post. It will be available sometime in the next few hours.

#CVE_2024_32113 #CVE_2024_36971 #eitw #activeexploitation #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #vulnerability #CVE #Apache #OFbiz #Android

##
screaminggoat at 2024-08-07T12:00:32.430Z ##

@therecord_media @jwarminsky how do we know that it's a zero-day? I get that this is the first time some of us are aware of CVE-2024-36971 but the CVE ID was assigned as early as 10 June 2024 by kernel.org.

##
oversecurity@mastodon.social at 2024-08-06T17:40:04.000Z ##

Google says Android zero-day was exploited in the wild

Google published information about an Android zero-day vulnerability tracked as CVE-2024-36971, which affects the Linux kernel.

ðï¸ [Therecord] https://link.is.it/rox91b

##
avoidthehack at 2024-08-06T15:17:10.626Z ##

#Google fixes #Android kernel zero-day exploited in targeted attacks

The zero-day is a use-after-free in the #Linux kernel's network route management and tracked as CVE-2024-36971. According to Google, this zero-day has been exploited in the wild.

The fix for this and another 46 vulnerabilities have been patched in the 5 AUG Android update.

Note: Google Pixels receive these updates monthly when released. Other Android phone manufacturers roll out these updates according to their own process/schedule, which may be delayed.

#security #cybersecurity #cve

https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/google-fixes-android-kernel-zero-day-exploited-in-targeted-attacks/

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-07T14:15:48.000Z ##

CISA: CISA Adds Two Known Exploited Vulnerabilities to Catalog
Hot off the press! CISA adds two CVEs to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog:

  • CVE-2024-32113 (9.1 critical) Apache OFBiz Path Traversal Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-36971 (7.8 high) Android Kernel Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

EDIT: In case anyone is wondering why it says "Access Denied", I'm too quick for CISA, and they haven't officially published the blog post. It will be available sometime in the next few hours.

#CVE_2024_32113 #CVE_2024_36971 #eitw #activeexploitation #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #vulnerability #CVE #Apache #OFbiz #Android

screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-07T12:00:32.000Z ##

oversecurity@mastodon.social at 2024-08-06T17:40:04.000Z ##

Google says Android zero-day was exploited in the wild

Google published information about an Android zero-day vulnerability tracked as CVE-2024-36971, which affects the Linux kernel.

ðï¸ [Therecord] https://link.is.it/rox91b

##
avoidthehack@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-06T15:17:10.000Z ##

#Google fixes #Android kernel zero-day exploited in targeted attacks

The zero-day is a use-after-free in the #Linux kernel's network route management and tracked as CVE-2024-36971. According to Google, this zero-day has been exploited in the wild.

The fix for this and another 46 vulnerabilities have been patched in the 5 AUG Android update.

Note: Google Pixels receive these updates monthly when released. Other Android phone manufacturers roll out these updates according to their own process/schedule, which may be delayed.

#security #cybersecurity #cve

https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/google-fixes-android-kernel-zero-day-exploited-in-targeted-attacks/

EDIT: CVE-2024-36971 appears to be a Linux Kernel vulnerability, potentially Use-After-Free (UAF). Clement Lecigne of Google's Threat Analysis Group (TAG) is credited in the NVD description, suggesting a link to commercial spyware vendors (CSVs). Google TAG has historically reported on CSVs.

##

CVE-2023-6448
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 3.94%

updated 2024-06-26T21:32:16

2 posts

Unitronics Vision Series PLCs and HMIs use default administrative passwords. An unauthenticated attacker with network access to a PLC or HMI can take administrative control of the system.

screaminggoat at 2024-08-08T14:13:51.516Z ##

U.S. Department of State Rewards for Justice: CyberAv3ngers
The U.S. Department of State Diplomatic Security Service (DSS) Rewards for Justice Program is offering a reward of up to $10 million USD for information or location on the following Iranian military officials:

  • Hamid Reza Lashgarian, head of the IRGCâs Cyber-Electronic Command (IRGC-CEC)
  • Hamid Homayunfal (IRGC-CEC senior official)
  • Mahdi Lashgarian (IRGC-CEC senior official)
  • Milad Mansuri (IRGC-CEC senior official)
  • Reza Mohammad Amin Saberian (IRGC-CEC senior official)
  • Mohammad Bagher Shirinkar (IRGC-CEC senior official)

The IRGC-CEC has been publicly attributed to the CyberAv3ngers "hacktivist" persona by the U.S. Government. CyberAv3ngers claimed responsibility for the 2023 hack of the Municipal Water Authority of Aliquippa in Pennsylvania right after Thanksgiving Day/Black Friday, in which programmable logic controllers, made by Israeli company Unitronics and used in water and other critical infrastructure systems, were hacked and defaced.

The security incident led to increased scrutiny of Industrial Control Systems and Operational Technnology (ICS-OT) and other critical infrastructure systems that have inherently weak security and vulnerable to state-sponsored cyberattacks. The use of a default password (1111) in the Unitronics PLC became CVE-2023-6448 (9.8 critical, assigned by CISA on 05 December 2023, and added to the KEV Catalog on 11 December 2023).

The turnaround time on the hacktivist-labeled cyberattack to public attribution was 1 week! After the Saturday attack on 25 November 2023, CISA pumped out a joint cybersecurity advisory late Friday night (8pm EST) on 01 December 2023 IRGC-Affiliated Cyber Actors Exploit PLCs in Multiple Sectors, Including U.S. Water and Wastewater Systems Facilities. U.S. Treasury's public attribution (in the form of sanctions) narrowed it down to the Cyber-Electronic Command of the IRGC.

#threatintel #IRGC #IRGC_CEC #Iran #cyberespionage #Unitronics #reward #cyberav3ngers

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-08T14:13:51.000Z ##

U.S. Department of State Rewards for Justice: CyberAv3ngers
The U.S. Department of State Diplomatic Security Service (DSS) Rewards for Justice Program is offering a reward of up to $10 million USD for information or location on the following Iranian military officials:

  • Hamid Reza Lashgarian, head of the IRGCâs Cyber-Electronic Command (IRGC-CEC)
  • Hamid Homayunfal (IRGC-CEC senior official)
  • Mahdi Lashgarian (IRGC-CEC senior official)
  • Milad Mansuri (IRGC-CEC senior official)
  • Reza Mohammad Amin Saberian (IRGC-CEC senior official)
  • Mohammad Bagher Shirinkar (IRGC-CEC senior official)

The IRGC-CEC has been publicly attributed to the CyberAv3ngers "hacktivist" persona by the U.S. Government. CyberAv3ngers claimed responsibility for the 2023 hack of the Municipal Water Authority of Aliquippa in Pennsylvania right after Thanksgiving Day/Black Friday, in which programmable logic controllers, made by Israeli company Unitronics and used in water and other critical infrastructure systems, were hacked and defaced.

The security incident led to increased scrutiny of Industrial Control Systems and Operational Technnology (ICS-OT) and other critical infrastructure systems that have inherently weak security and vulnerable to state-sponsored cyberattacks. The use of a default password (1111) in the Unitronics PLC became CVE-2023-6448 (9.8 critical, assigned by CISA on 05 December 2023, and added to the KEV Catalog on 11 December 2023).

The turnaround time on the hacktivist-labeled cyberattack to public attribution was 1 week! After the Saturday attack on 25 November 2023, CISA pumped out a joint cybersecurity advisory late Friday night (8pm EST) on 01 December 2023 IRGC-Affiliated Cyber Actors Exploit PLCs in Multiple Sectors, Including U.S. Water and Wastewater Systems Facilities. U.S. Treasury's public attribution (in the form of sanctions) narrowed it down to the Cyber-Electronic Command of the IRGC.

CVE-2024-30103
(8.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.09%

updated 2024-06-11T18:30:56

8 posts

Microsoft Outlook Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

screaminggoat at 2024-08-12T15:27:47.400Z ##

Morphisec: Technical Analysis: CVE-2024-30103
As promised 2 months ago, Morphisec provides a technical analysis (but no proof of concept?) of CVE-2024-30103 (CVSSv3: 8.8 high, disclosed 11 June 2024 by Microsoft) Microsoft Outlook Remote Code Execution Vulnerability. (see parent toots above).
It mostly confirms what Robel Campbell of Blackpoint Cyber assessed back on 21 June 2024: that it is a bypass for a previously patched vulnerability CVE-2024-21378, and it requires valid credentials (authentication).
I was expecting more information to be honest.

cc: @GossiTheDog h/t: @mttaggart

#CVE_2024_30103 #CVE_2024_21378 #MSRC #Microsoft #Outlook #vulnerability #CVE

##

CVE-2023-33202
(5.5 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-05-23T21:12:27

2 posts

Bouncy Castle for Java before 1.73 contains a potential Denial of Service (DoS) issue within the Bouncy Castle org.bouncycastle.openssl.PEMParser class. This class parses OpenSSL PEM encoded streams containing X.509 certificates, PKCS8 encoded keys, and PKCS7 objects. Parsing a file that has crafted ASN.1 data through the PEMParser causes an OutOfMemoryError, which can enable a denial of service a

soatok@furry.engineer at 2024-08-06T19:58:59.000Z ##

My recent XMPP + OMEMO blog post wasn't very clear about the risk of CVE-2023-33202, so I spelled it out a bit clearer: https://soatok.blog/2024/08/04/against-xmppomemo/

##
soatok@soatok.blog at 2024-08-04T09:12:03.000Z ##

XMPP is a messaging protocol (among other things) that needs no introduction to any technical audience. Its various implementations have proliferated through technical communities for decades.

Many large tech companies today used to run XMPP servers. However, the basic protocol transmitted plaintext. If you were lucky, it was plaintext over SSL/TLS, but servers could still see all of your message contents.

OMEMO (XEP-0384) is an attempt to staple end-to-end encryption onto the XMPP ecosystem.

Itâs largely inspired by, and based on, an earlier version of the Signal protocol, so you might be tempted to believing that itâs good.

In my opinion, itâs not.

OMEMO is not the worst attempt at making XMPP encrypted (see: XEP-0027 for that), but it still doesnât meet the bar for the kind of private messaging app that Signal is, and is not a viable competitor to Signal.

To understand why this is true, you only need check whether OMEMO is on by default (it isnât), or whether OMEMO can be turned off even if your client supports it (it can).

Both of these conditions fail the requirements I outlined under the End-to-End Encryption header in that other blog post.

And thatâs all that I should have needed to say on the matter.

Art: Harubaki

Unfortunately, the Internet is full of cargo cults built around specific technologies, and their followers have an emotional interest in muddying the waters.

Criticize one, and their rivals will come out of the woodwork to say, âThis is why I use $FooBar instead of $BazQuux!â and insist that their preferred solution is the secure oneâwith all the confident incorrectness of a climate change denier.

Art: AJ

Let me explain why I donât recommend XMPP and OMEMO for private messaging.

But before I do, a quick reminder that me criticizing XMPP+OMEMO isnât an endorsement of weird or stupid alternatives, like using PGP.

Also, this post is about the entire XMPP + OMEMO ecosystem, not just the OMEMO specification.

Art: ScruffKerfluff

Why People Like XMPP

Quite simply, people like XMPP because itâs federated, which means they can control who gets access to their data. This is also one reason why people like Matrix, Mastodon, NextCloud, etc. It gives them a sense of control over their data that a centralized platform doesnât. You can feel like youâre controlling your own destiny, whether or not thatâs true. And those emotions can be a powerful thing.

Unlike Moxie, I donât inherently think federated technology is always bad.

There are mechanisms you can employ to roll the entire ecosystem forward and keep everyone up-to-date with security fixes to an underlying protocol. Being frozen in time is a real problem in federation, but not an inevitability.

Unfortunately, XMPP is the perfect exhibit for anyone that wants to argue in favor of Moxieâs perspective on federation.

OMEMO Problem 1: Protocol Freeze

When I decided to set out to survey the XMPP+OMEMO ecosystem, the first question that came to mind is, âWhich implementation is everyone using?â

The answer is probably Conversations. Other answers I heard were Gajim and forks of Conversations.

Weâll get back to Conversations later, but right now, I want to address a bigger problem with the XMPP+OMEMO ecosystem.

The latest draft of XEP-0384 is version 0.8.3, published in January 2022.

Despite this, almost every OMEMO implementation I can find is still on version 0.3.0 (or earlier) of the OMEMO specification.

Art: CMYKat

The easiest way to tell if they arenât implementing version 0.4.0 or newer is the absence of AES-256-CBC in their codebase.

See for yourself. All of the following implement version 0.3.0 or older of the OMEMO specification:

  • libomemo, dependents:
    • weechat-xmpp
  • Conversations, forks:
    • blabber.im
    • Monocles
    • Quicksy
    • Snikket
  • Converse.js
  • Gajim
  • jaxmpp, dependents:
    • Stork IM
  • jabber-web
  • MartinOMEMO, dependents:
    • Siskin IM

The only implementations I found that supported newer protocol versions were Profanity and Kaidan (via QXmpp).

EDIT: Thanks to tant for pointing me to this list of versions.

What To Even Focus On?

A question comes to mind: Which version of the specification should an enterprising security researcher look at?

Art: CMYKat

The latest version available online, or an ancient version thatâs still widely used?

If I find a problem in the latest draft of the specification, some will say thatâs a non-issue because the spec is âexperimentalâ and therefore should not implemented yet.

If I find a problem in the older draft of the specification, some will insist that those are known problems with an older version of the spec, and that people âshouldâ be on the newer version if they expect to be secure.

Even worse, thereâs probably some overlap between the two sets of people.

Regardless, anyone whoâs vested in improving the security of the XMPP+OMEMO ecosystem is at an impasse right out of the gate. Thatâs not a good place to be in.

OMEMO Problem 2: YOLO Crypto

OMEMO doesnât attempt to provide even the vaguest rationale for its design choices, and appears to approach cryptography protocol specification with a care-free attitude.

To put it mildly, this is the wrong way to approach cryptography. This is best explained with a concrete example.

Version 0.3.0 of XEP-0384 used AES-128-GCM to encrypt messages. (As we saw in the previous section, this is the version almost everyone is actually using.)

Version 0.4.0 was updated to use AES-256-CBC + HMAC-SHA-256 (Encrypt then HMAC), as Signal does.

Version 0.7.0 introduced yet another protocol change: The HMAC-SHA-256 authentication tag is now truncated to 128 bits.

And what was the changelog message for version 0.7.0?

Various fixes, clarifications and general improvements.

CHANGELOG, XEP-0384 0.7.0

Youâve got to be fucking kidding me.

Harubaki

So hereâs the thing: These protocols all provide different security properties, and some of these differences are subtle. Switching from one to the other is the sort of change that should be accompanied by a clear reason.

See, for example, the PASETO v3/v4 rationale doc. That is the level of detail Iâd want to see in OMEMOâs specification, especially the changelog. OMEMOâs rationale isnât merely inadequate, itâs totally absent!

Technical Correction (2024-08-06)

A few people (or maybe the same person under different alts? Didnât check, donât really care) have pointed out that this section is not technically correct.

Apparently, while the actual steps in the encryption and decryption algorithms didnât mention truncation at all, this was alluded to earlier in an earlier section.

Iâm not going to significantly alter what I originally wrote above, because the earlier versions of the spec were poorly written and the instructions where absent from the section they needed to be in.

OMEMO Encryption Through the Ages

Before Version 0.4.0

AES-128-GCM doesnât commit to the key, which can lead to an attack that we call âInvisible Salamandersâ.

Historically, this was exploited in âabuse reportingâ scenarios, but as I explained in my Threema disclosures, it can sometimes come up in group messaging scenarios.

For flavor, I wrote a GCM exploit in PHP for part of the DEFCON Fursâ badge challenge one year. Itâs not a difficult one to pull off.

But if youâre in a setup where you only have one valid key for a given ciphertext, thatâs not really a problem.

A bigger concern with this algorithm is that youâre constrained to 96-bit nonces, so if youâre using the same key for multiple messages, you have to worry about symmetric wear-out.

That being said, we can kind of summarize this as a short, reusable list.

  • Key entropy: 128 bits
  • Key commitment security: None
  • Safety limit: messages, each with a max length of bytes.
  • Authentication tag length: 128 bits
  • Authentication security: 128 bits (polynomial MAC)

Version 0.4.0 â 0.6.0

As mentioned previously, version 0.4.0 of the OMEMO specification moved towards AES-256-CBC + HMAC-SHA-256 for Stanza Content Encryption.

This is congruent with what Signal does, so I wonât belabor the point.

If you implement the encryption algorithm faithfully from the specificationâs order of operations, truncation is omitted. However, it does get a passing mention in the double ratchet section, so the authors can argue it was intended âall alongâ.

  • Key entropy: 256 bits
  • Key commitment security: 128 bits 64 bits
  • Safety limit: Itâs complicated. It can range from to bytes.
  • Authentication tag length: 256 bits 128 bits (see edit)
  • Authentication security: 128 bits 64 bits (cryptographic hash function)

EDIT: As mentioned above, this is actually not correct, because of an easy-to-miss detail in a previous section. There is no relevant encryption protocol change between 0.4.0 and 0.7.0.

Version 0.7.0 and Newer

And now we get to the latest version of the protocol, which is like the previous flavor, but now they truncate the HMAC-SHA-256 authentication tag to 128 bits in the actual steps to be performed.

Specifications should provide clear, unambiguous instructions for implementors. The OMEMO specification authors have failed to do this.

Interestingly, even the current version (0.8.3) doesnât instruct implementations to use constant-time comparison for the truncated authentication tag in the decrypt path.

Surely, that wonât be a problem, right?

But to be congruent with the other sections in this historical breakdown, version 0.7.0+ looks like this:

  • Key entropy: 256 bits
  • Key commitment security: 64 bits
  • Safety limit: Itâs complicated. It can range from to bytes.
  • Authentication tag length: 128 bits
  • Authentication security: 64 bits (cryptographic hash function)

Remarks

Because there is no rationale given for this sudden square-root reduction in security against existential forgery attacks (EDIT: not correct, it was always truncated, just poorly written), we kind of have to fill in the gaps and assume it was because of some kind of performance or bandwidth considerations.

But even that doesnât really justify it, does it?

Youâre only saving 16 bytes of bandwidth by truncating the MAC. Meanwhile, the actual ciphertext blobs are being encoded with base64, which adds 33% of overhead.

For any message larger than 48 bytes, this base64 encoding will dominate the bandwidth consumption more than using the full HMAC tag would.

CMYKat

Is truncating the HMAC tag to to 128 bits still secure? According to Signal, yes, it is. And I offer no disagreement to Signalâs assessment here.

The problem is, as Iâve said repeatedly, OMEMOâs specification makes no attempt to justify their design decisions.

The âwhy?â is left as an exercise to the reader, and Iâm not convinced that they themselves fully know the answer to that question.

OMEMO Problem 3: Market Penetration

I alluded to this above, but it bears repeating: Even if the previous two problems were resolved overnight, itâs entirely possible to use XMPP without encryption.

Further, you can disable OMEMO even if youâre using a client that supports OMEMO.

When I compare it to Signal, whose users always have end-to-end encryption, XMPP + OMEMO falls short of what is required to be a secure private messaging app.

XMPP+OMEMO evangelists are quick to point out that Conversations, the favored implementation, lets you enforce âalways use encryptionâ mode. This is a damn good idea, but thereâs no universal guarantee that all clients will do this, nor make it the default behavior.

On that note, letâs talk about Conversations.

OMEMO Problem 4: Youâre not ready for that Conversation

Conversations is, from the best I can gather, the most popular XMPP client with OMEMO support.

If youâre going to discuss OMEMO, in practical terms, you need to look at the most popular implementation of OMEMO to have an informed opinion on the matter. Only focusing on the specification, rathe than actual implementations, would be a foolhardy endeavor.

Conversations appears to follow the âeverything but the kitchen sinkâ methodology to managing their complexity.

Just looking at the crypto folder, I count the following:

  1. Code that implements OpenPGP functions (signing, encryption)
  2. X.509 certificate validation for XMPP domains based on BouncyCastle
  3. An entire first-class SASL implementation, rather than a third-party library
  4. Finally, their OMEMO implementation (still named Axolotl) that depends on libsignal

Update (2024-08-09): An earlier version of this blog post criticized them for having two PGP classes in the crypto folder.

The second one (PgpDecryptionService.java) appeared to call a separate API from the one next to it, which seemed like a legacy code path that was in need of refactoring away.

A closer examination reveals that it calls a Service class that in turn calls the first PGP class (PgpEngine.java), so I retracted that item from the above list.

To be clear: These arenât separate dependencies that Conversations pulls in to implement plugin supports. Theyâre first-party cryptographic implementations all within this Android appâs codebase.

(Some of them also have third-party dependencies to boot, but thatâs generally okay.)

The only thing they didnât include is their own first-party TLS implementation forked from, like, OpenSSL 1.0.2f. That wouldâve filled my Bingo card.

Art by AJ

Your Version Check Bounced

The latest version of Conversations depends on version 1.64 of the Bouncy Castle S/MIME implementation (October 2019), despite 1.70 being the latest that supports Java 1.5 (and 1.78 being the latest overall, but requires Java 1.8).

This means the following security enhancements and fixes are absent in the version Conversations depends on:

  • Client-side OCSP Stapling was added in v1.65
  • TLS 1.3 support was added in v1.68
  • CVE-2023-33202, a DoS vulnerability in ASN.1 reachable through the PEM parser (i.e., any of the X.509 or OpenPGP code referenced above) is fixed in version v1.73.

The last one (CVE-2023-33202) is pernicious. Although itâs reachable through any usage of BouncyCastleâs Java PEM parser, the root cause is the underlying ASN.1 code, which means the domain verifier code is probably affected.

Why is Conversations in August 2024 still using an October 2019 version of their cryptography library?

Why am I pointing this out today when a component it provides that Conversations actually uses had a security fix in July 2023?

Itâs not just BouncyCastle, either. Conversations also depends on a version of libsignal that was archived in 2022.

How We Got Here

Though it may be tempting for some readers to assign blame, let me be very clear: Doing so isnât helpful, so donât.

XMPP was a well-intentioned open protocol and Internet Standard. OMEMO was the least-bad effort to staple encryption onto XMPP.

If Conversations hadnât cornered the XMPP market in recent years, the lack of discipline in complexity management (or a Dependabot or Semgrep integration, for that matter) would be a minor annoyance.

A lot of things had to go wrong for things to get as bad as they are.

Maybe part of the blame is a lack of investment or innovation in the XMPP developer community.

Maybe there should have been more dialogue between the security community and the XMPP Standards Foundation.

But the one thing I am certain of is the conclusion to this whole piece.

In Conclusion

As things stand today, I cannot recommend anyone use XMPP + OMEMO.

From the lack of a mechanism to keep implementations up-to-date with protocol versions, to a lack of clear rationale for protocol design decisions, to ecosystem issues with both the app availability and their third-party open source dependencies, to the most popular app (Conversations) being an absolute mess of complications, XMPP+OMEMO hasnât earned my trust.

Itâs possible that these flaws are correctable, and some future iteration of OMEMO will be better. Itâs also possible that XMPPâs ecosystem will decide to make end-to-end encryption a non-optional component for all XMPP clients.

But I certainly wouldnât bet my personal safety on good things happening; especially because of anything I wrote. Iâm just some furry with a blog, after all.

CMYKat

âDonât care, gonna keep using it!â

Thatâs fine. Iâm not anyoneâs boss or parent.

But in return, I really donât appreciate unsolicited evangelism towards any technology.

Itâs even worse when said evangelism is shouted over my informed opinions about cryptographic software. So, please donât do that.

Addendum (2024-08-06)

Tim Henkes, one of the OMEMO authors, wrote a very tedious comment. The TL;DR of it is âyou should distinguish between specification criticism and client software criticism, also truncation was in 0.4.0â.

I made the relevant changes above, because technical accuracy is important to me, but wasnât interested in further involving myself with their project. So I replied saying as such.

Hereâs a screenshot of their reply:

Iâm just gonna let that speak for itself.

https://soatok.blog/2024/08/04/against-xmppomemo/

#cryptography #endToEndEncryption #softwareSecurity

screaminggoat at 2024-08-13T18:37:30.648Z ##

Juniper: The Hidden Door: How CVE-2024-23897 Enabled Ransomware Attack on Indian Banks
In case you haven't patched your Jenkins server already, CVE-2024-23897 (9.8 critical, disclosed 24 January 2024 by Jenkins, has Proof of Concept) is still being actively exploited. This time, Juniper pivots off of CloudSEK research and found that the ransomware group RansomEXX leveraged CVE-2024-23897 to target Indian banks (01 August 2024 cyberattack on Brontoo Technology Solutions). Technical analysis of the vulnerability and the proof of concept provided. No IOC available.

#CVE_2024_23897 #Jenkins #vulnerability #CVE #eitw #activeexploitation #threatintel #ransomware

##
screaminggoat at 2024-08-05T14:39:49.977Z ##

CloudSEK has two different reporting on CVE-2024-23897 (9.8 critical, disclosed 24 January 2024, has Proof of Concept) exploitation:

  • BORN Group Supply Chain Breach: In-Depth Analysis of Intelbroker's Jenkins Exploitation
  • Exposing the Exploitation: How CVE-2024-23897 Led to the Compromise of Github Repos via Jenkins LFI Vulnerability

CloudSEK claims that threat actor IntelBroker exploits CVE-2024-23897 on an exposed Jenkins server in order to steal SSH keys to access IT Service Provider Born Group's GitHub repository and exfiltrate sensitive data from multiple clients. IOC provided.

The second article is more a warning about active exploitation of CVE-2024-23897. Attackers accessed sensitive files, decrypted credentials, and used them to infiltrate private repositories. No IOC.

#threatintel #CVE_2024_23897 #activeexploitation #vulnerability #Jenkins #eitw #Intelbroker #IOC

##

C-EDGE (a joint venture between TCS and SBI), experienced a ransomware attack that disrupted India's banking ecosystem. The attack originated from a misconfigured Jenkins server at Brontoo Technology Solutions, vulnerable to CVE-2024-23897, a local file inclusion (LFI) vulnerability. Exploiting this vulnerability, the attackers gained secure shell access by reading private keys, facilitated by an open port 22.

CVE-2024-21378

1 repos

screaminggoat at 2024-08-12T15:27:47.400Z ##

Morphisec: Technical Analysis: CVE-2024-30103
As promised 2 months ago, Morphisec provides a technical analysis (but no proof of concept?) of CVE-2024-30103 (CVSSv3: 8.8 high, disclosed 11 June 2024 by Microsoft) Microsoft Outlook Remote Code Execution Vulnerability. (see parent toots above).
It mostly confirms what Robel Campbell of Blackpoint Cyber assessed back on 21 June 2024: that it is a bypass for a previously patched vulnerability CVE-2024-21378, and it requires valid credentials (authentication).
I was expecting more information to be honest.

cc: @GossiTheDog h/t: @mttaggart

#CVE_2024_30103 #CVE_2024_21378 #MSRC #Microsoft #Outlook #vulnerability #CVE

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-06T16:18:01.000Z ##

@da_667 My takeaway is that CVE-2024-38856 is a patch-bypass of CVE-2024-36104, which is a path traversal. I had an issue with SonicWall calling it a zero-day, which implied that it was known to threat actors. No evidence given.

PoC diffing with https://github.com/Mr-xn/CVE-2024-32113

##

CVE-2024-20693
(7.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-04-09T18:30:25

2 posts

Windows Kernel Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability

1 repos

#search_error

xnyhps at 2024-08-13T18:20:10.256Z ##

In our writeup https://sector7.computest.nl/post/2024-06-cve-2024-20693-windows-cached-code-signature-manipulation/ about CVE-2024-20693, we noted that Microsoft did not structurally address the trust of "$KERNEL.*" Extended Attributes on SMB shares. Today's Patch Tuesday addresses #CVE-2024-38133, doing the same thing again, but in this case even an USB disk would work!

I think this may be the first time we got an "Exploitation More Likely", so achievement unlocked I guess?

#Microsoft #vulnerability #Windows #PatchTuesday

##
xnyhps@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-13T18:20:10.000Z ##

In our writeup https://sector7.computest.nl/post/2024-06-cve-2024-20693-windows-cached-code-signature-manipulation/ about CVE-2024-20693, we noted that Microsoft did not structurally address the trust of "$KERNEL.*" Extended Attributes on SMB shares. Today's Patch Tuesday addresses #CVE-2024-38133, doing the same thing again, but in this case even an USB disk would work!

I think this may be the first time we got an "Exploitation More Likely", so achievement unlocked I guess?

#Microsoft #vulnerability #Windows #PatchTuesday

##

CVE-2021-33294
(5.5 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-04-04T06:13:22

1 posts

In elfutils 0.183, an infinite loop was found in the function handle_symtab in readelf.c .Which allows attackers to cause a denial of service (infinite loop) via crafted file.

1 repos

#search_error

patrick@o0o.social at 2024-08-07T08:00:57.000Z ##

Have to go through them one by one and right now saw this statement from Red Hat: Upstream would categorize this as a simple bug, not a security issue. Since most elfutils tools are run in short-lived, local, interactive, development contexts rather than remotely "in production", we generally treat malfunctions as ordinary bugs rather than security vulnerabilities.

So please, vulnerability researchers, not all fricking bugs are vulnerabilities; things like this are wasting time of so many different people's time

source: https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2021-33294

#security #vulnerability #cve

##

CVE-2024-1973
(8.6 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-03-26T00:32:00

1 posts

By leveraging the vulnerability, lower-privileged users of Content Manager can manipulate Content Manager clients to elevate privileges and perform unauthorized operations.

jabbrwcky at 2024-08-15T08:40:24.954Z ##

Coming up on 5 months since publication of CVE-2024-1973, a sev 8.5 priv elevation vuln affecting an EDRM system used extensively in govt. It's still not patched by Opentext. They took a stab at a patch, it broke stuff and rather than fix it they're now saying they'll roll it up into next major version due in Q4 sometime. Because y'know it's only vast amounts of confidential data at stake, not like it's anything important. And govt won't ever change systems because it's too hard so vendors can run roughshod over them.

##

CVE-2024-23717(CVSS UNKNOWN)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-03-11T18:31:15

2 posts

In access_secure_service_from_temp_bond of btm_sec.cc, there is a possible way to achieve keystroke injection due to improper input validation. This could lead to remote (proximal/adjacent) escalation of privilege with no additional execution privileges needed. User interaction is not needed for exploitation.

tulpa@fosstodon.org at 2024-08-07T16:30:44.000Z ##

I just learned that this was a thing, from about 18 months ago: https://vulert.com/vuln-db/CVE-2024-23717

Attackers could exploit Bluetooth to inject keystrokes onto affected phones without any user interaction at all.

Keep Bluetooth disabled if you're not using it, folks. The 's' in "Bluetooth" is for "security".

#infosec #bluetooth

##
tulpa@fosstodon.org at 2024-08-07T16:30:44.000Z ##

Keep Bluetooth disabled if you're not using it, folks. The 's' in "Bluetooth" is for "security".

GossiTheDog@cyberplace.social at 2024-08-16T06:25:12.000Z ##

@malwaretech havenât looked at this CVE as my personal life is busy burning down, but I was at Microsoft for CVE-2021-24094 (IPv6 RCE) and a massive song and dance was made about that internally and externally, despite the finders not even being able to prove RCE and it having almost zero real world exploitability.

Not saying the same thing is happening, but sometimes the announcements are missing important context.

AAKL@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-13T14:44:55.000Z ##

- #Microsoft Azure Health Bot Server-Side Request Forgery (Data Connection Endpoints) - CVE-2024-38109 (critical) https://www.tenable.com/security/research/tra-2024-27

- Microsoft Azure Health Bot Server-Side Request Forgery (FHIR Endpoint Validation) (high) https://www.tenable.com/security/research/tra-2024-28

- Schneider Electric Accutech Manager RFManagerService.exe Denial of Service - CVE-2024-6918 (high) https://www.tenable.com/security/research/tra-2024-29 @tenable

##

CVE-2024-37375
(0 None)

EPSS: 0.00%

2 posts

N/A

screaminggoat at 2024-08-07T18:38:24.470Z ##

Ivanti and Fortinet have unpatched vulnerabilities in their VPN products!
Akamai, in their blog post Living off the VPN â Exploring VPN Post-Exploitation Techniques, talk about techniques that can be used by threat actors after compromising a VPN server to further escalate their intrusion. The key takeaway is that the vulnerability disclosure was published 133 days after initial notification to Ivanti and Fortinet:

  • CVE-2024-37374 (unknown CVSS score) Ivanti hard-coded key issue?
  • CVE-2024-37375 (unknown CVSS score) Ivanti MDM cleartext passwords issue?
  • Fortinet custom encryption key bypass issue (no CVE ID assigned)

Fortinet informed us that after additional consideration, they decided to not fix the custom encryption key bypass as it âdoes not cross a security boundaryâ

If the original Ivanti Connect Secure exploited zero-day fiasco hasn't scared you off of their products, this is your wakeup call. As @cadey would say: "No way to prevent this" say users of only VPN where this regularly happens

cc: @campuscodi (who else wants to be notified of issues like this?)

#CVE_2024_37374 #CVE_2024_37375 #Fortinet #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #FortiGate

CVE-2024-20453
(0 None)

EPSS: 0.00%

2 posts

N/A

screaminggoat at 2024-08-07T16:11:07.821Z ##

Cisco security advisories:

  • Cisco Identity Services Engine Stored Cross-Site Scripting Vulnerabilities
    • CVE-2024-20443 (5.4 medium) A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco ISE could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to conduct an XSS attack against a user of the interface.
    • CVE-2024-20479 (4.8 medium) A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco ISE could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to conduct an XSS attack against a user of the interface.
  • Cisco Small Business SPA300 Series and SPA500 Series IP Phones Web UI Vulnerabilities
    • CVE-2024-20450 (9.8 critical) unauth RCE
    • CVE-2024-20452 (9.8 critical) unauth RCE
    • CVE-2024-20454 (9.8 critical) unauth RCE
    • CVE-2024-20451 (7.5 high) unauth DoS
    • CVE-2024-20453 (7.5 high) unauth DoS

The Cisco Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) is not aware of any public announcements or malicious use of the vulnerabilities that are described in this advisory.

#Cisco #PatchTuesday #vulnerability #cve

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-07T16:11:07.000Z ##

Cisco security advisories:

  • Cisco Identity Services Engine Stored Cross-Site Scripting Vulnerabilities
    • CVE-2024-20443 (5.4 medium) A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco ISE could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to conduct an XSS attack against a user of the interface.
    • CVE-2024-20479 (4.8 medium) A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco ISE could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to conduct an XSS attack against a user of the interface.
  • Cisco Small Business SPA300 Series and SPA500 Series IP Phones Web UI Vulnerabilities
    • CVE-2024-20450 (9.8 critical) unauth RCE
    • CVE-2024-20452 (9.8 critical) unauth RCE
    • CVE-2024-20454 (9.8 critical) unauth RCE
    • CVE-2024-20451 (7.5 high) unauth DoS
    • CVE-2024-20453 (7.5 high) unauth DoS

The Cisco Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) is not aware of any public announcements or malicious use of the vulnerabilities that are described in this advisory.
